section.title: The script configuration file
section.para: The script configuration file is a set of commands that are parsed and executed by &combustion; in a &tr-up; shell. This article provides examples of configuration tasks performed by &combustion;.

important.title: Include interpreter declaration
important.para: As the script file is interpreted by Bash, always start the file with the interpreter declaration at its first line:

section.para: To log in to your system, include at least the &rootuser; password. However, it is recommended to establish the authentication using SSH keys. If you need to use a &rootuser; password, make sure to configure a secure password. If you use a randomly generated password, use at least 10 characters. If you create your password manually, use even more than 10 characters and combine uppercase and lowercase letters and numbers.

section.title: Partitioning
section.para: &alpshort; raw images are delivered with a default partitioning scheme as described in . You might want to use a different partitioning. The following set of example snippets moves the /home to a different partition.

note.title: Performing changes outside of directories included in snapshots
note.para: The following script performs changes that are not included in snapshots. If the script fails and the snapshot is discarded, some changes remain visible and cannot be reverted, for example, the changes to the /dev/vdb device.

section.para: The following snippet creates a GPT partitioning schema with a single partition on the /dev/vdb device:
section.screen:
sfdisk /dev/vdb <<EOF label: gpt type=linux EOF
partition=/dev/vdb1
section.para: The partition is formatted to BTRFS:
Possible content of /home is moved to the new /home folder location by the following snippet:
The snippet below removes an old entry in /etc/fstab and creates a new entry:
section.screen: awk -i inplace '$2 != "/home"' /etc/fstab echo "$(blkid -o export ${partition} | grep ^UUID=) /home btrfs defaults 0 0" >>/etc/fstab
